Nashville — Shownotes S01E05

By:   |  Mailed on: November 12, 2012

Dear , ,

Dear Cast and Crew of Nashville, S1E05 – “Move It on Over”

Episode synopsis:
Rayna thinks about moving on when Deacon sets boundaries on their relationship; tension between Gunnar and Avery puts pressure on Scarlett; and as Juliette struggles with her mother’s addictions, Deacon is reminded of difficult moments in his past.

Original air date:
November 7, 2012

Shownotes:

  • Starting with a song. This episode is better already.
  • Rayna won’t release a greatest hits album until she’s 70? Sounds about right, since her view of the music industry is stuck in the 70s as well.
  • So Teddy’s big secret with Peggy is embezzlement, not embeddingment?
  • 90s music video alert: Silk sheets floating on a sound stage!
  • Scarlett and Gunner are performing a song for Lady Antebellum’s management. Are they setting up the first country cameo (and suggesting Lady Antebellum don’t write their own songs)?
  • I guess Juliette moved. She used to drive to her own front gate, now gawkers are watching her family drama spill out the front door and into the street.
  • Avery just turned himself on by offering to play guitar. Creepy.
  • To see what a constipated middle-aged man looks like, observe Rayna’s manager’s face when Rayna says she’ll try writing her own songs.
  • Deacon swoops in to send Juliette’s mom to rehab. Patent pending on this reality show: “Celebrity Intervention! Your favourtie star, telling you to shape the fuck up!”
  • Once again, a song by Scarlett and Gunner steals the show. Oh, wait. Avery just stole their show with a guitar solo. Such beautiful tension coming out of that steal guitar…
  • Props to the casting director for finding an actress (Sylvia Jefferies) who actually looks like an addict to play Juliette’s mom.
  • Juliette just got bitch slapped – but not for being a bitch, for once.
  • Oh, now Juliette’s really moving houses. Again?…
  • Like a classy comedian, Deacon knows how to handle a heckler with grace.
  • Wait, now Deacon knocks out the heckler, after the show, when the guy apologizes? I’m confused.
  • Wow. Rayna just set a new standard in rejection. Not accepting someone’s (Deacon’s) one collect-phone call from prison.
  • “How complicated” does Gunner want to make his relationship with Hailey? Sex in the office complicated.
  • After the diss of the decade, Deacon let’s Rayna sellout their song to a makeup company? I guess he’s waiting until the commercial airs before punching her out, too.

Closing comments: Restraint is apparently the ultimate revenge in this evening soap opera. Or at least withholding retribution until it feels less predictable. It’s a good tactic, and the abundance of songs this episode was a welcome return after last week. Refraining from celebrity cameos proves the show is clearly not aiming to be the Entourage of country music, and may just reference the genre’s biggest (retired) stars in an attempt to forge their own new ones. 

Signed,

Christopher Redmond
